questions.text: In patients with infective endocarditis, the vegetations are most commonly present on:
questions.solution:
The mitral valve is the most common valve affected in infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is the infection of the endocardial layer of the heart. It may involve the endocardial layer over the heart valves, mural endocardium, or septum. However, it can also affect intracardiac devices.

Note: Infection of the arteriovenous shunts and the arterio-arterial shunt is called infective endarteritis and not infective endocarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardiac manifestation of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Roth's spots are not the cardiac manifestation of infective endocarditis (IE). They are the immunological phenomenon seen in patients with infective endocarditis.

Symptoms of infective endocarditis can be broadly divided into cardiac and non-cardiac manifestations. Non-cardiac manifestations of infective endocarditis are further divided into immunologic and vascular phenomena.

  • Cardiac manifestations of IE:
    • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
    • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
    • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
    • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
    • Embolization of coronary arteries
  • Non-cardiac manifestations of IE:
    • Immunological phenomena (mnemonic ROGeR):
      • Osler's nodes- small, tender, red papules that are present on the distal finger and toe pads.
      • Roth's spots- white-centered retinal hemorrhages
      • Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis
      • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
    • Vascular phenomena:
      • Janeway lesions- these are faint, red, macular, painless lesions, commonly present on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.
      • Major arterial emboli
      • Septic pulmonary infarct
      • Mycotic aneurysm
      • Intracranial hemorrhages
      • Conjunctival hemorrhages
      • Splenic abscess
      • Cerebral abscess

The image below shows Roth spot on the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the minor criteria of modified Duke criteria for clinical diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion
Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria

questions.solution:
Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria was earlier a minor criterion but is now removed.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: According to the modified Duke criteria, a single positive blood culture is included in the major criteria for which organism?
questions.solution:
According to modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800 is included in the major criteria.

questions.text: A known IV drug abuser is referred to medicine OPD from the de-addiction wing due to prolonged fever and new-onset seizures. His fever has been present for 2 weeks and did not come down with antibiotics. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation. Multiple painless skin lesions are present on the hands. What are these lesions?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's nodes. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

Osler nodes & Janeway lesions share similar pathogenesis, arises from micro-emboli embedding in different anatomical sites. Pain from Osler nodes is associated with emboli lodging in the glomus apparatus of the dermis. Histologically, both lesions show septic micro-emboli with dermal micro-abscess formation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the vegetations seen in infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Present mainly along the lines of closure
Present on both side of valve leaflets

questions.solution:

  • Large and irregular

questions.text: You are asked to collect blood samples for culture from a patient suspected to have infective endocarditis by a typical pathogen. Choose the correct statement for the same.

choices.text: 3 separate culture sets - two aerobic and one anaerobic
3 separate culture sets - two anaerobic and one aerobic
2 separate culture sets - one aerobic and one anaerobic

questions.solution:
Option D. According to the Modified Duke 2023 Criteria for infective endocarditis, when a typical organism is suspected, two separate culture sets are required, one aerobic and one anaerobic.
If an atypical organism is suspected, three or more separate culture sets are used. 

According to the new Duke’s criteria, there is no specific timing to draw blood for blood culture.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presented with malaise, fatigue, and rigors for 1 week. Multiple puncture sites were present on the forearm along with sclerosed veins. His temperature on admission was 38.5 °C. Examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur which was loudest at the left sternal edge. Three sets of blood cultures were taken. questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is most likely to be positive in cultures as it is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers.

Endocarditis in injection drug users is mostly right-sided and involves the tricuspid valve.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis is the prior use of antibiotics.

Some proportion of patients with endocarditis have negative blood cultures. The important causes are:

  • Prior antibiotic use (most common cause)
  • IE due to fastidious organisms or unusual pathogens or fungi such as:
    • Streptococci (Granulicatella and Abiotrophia species)
    • HACEK organisms
    • Coxiella burnetii
    • Bartonella species
    • Brucella
    • Tropheryma whipplei

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman with a history of moderate aortic stenosis presented with fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats for 2 weeks. Blood tests showed the following. Echocardiography revealed an intracardiac mass on the mitral valve. Blood cultures showed growth of Streptococcus gallolyticus. What additional investigation should be performed?

Hb- 9.9 g/dL

WBC count- 16.0 × 10^9 /L

CRP- 187 mg/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and laboratory investigations are suggestive of infective endocarditis caused due to Streptococcus gallolyticus. In this condition, a colonoscopy should be performed.

Streptococcus gallolyticus originates from the gastrointestinal tract and is associated with polyps and colon cancer. Hence, the presence of this organism in the vegetation of infective endocarditis should warrant a gastrointestinal investigation.

questions.text: Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred over transthoracic echocardiography as initial investigation in all of the following patients, except:

choices.text: Patient with suspected prosthetic valve endocarditis
Patient with suspected IE presenting with fever
Patient with suspected IE with a new onset regurgitant murmur
Patient with suspected IE who has previous history of IE

questions.solution:
For a patient with low suspicion of IE, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) will be done as an initial investigation.

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is preferred as the initial investigation in all high-risk patients and/or in patients where a high clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis (IE) exists. 

TEE is also preferred over TTE for evaluating:

  • Vegetations < 2mm in diameter
  • Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE)
  • Detection of myocardial abscess
  • Detection of valve perforation
  • Detection of intracardiac fistulae
  • Detection of vegetations in a patient with a cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions have the lowest risk of developing infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Atrial septal defect (ASD) is associated with a very low incidence of IE. In ASD, the velocity of the shunt blood is low due to the decreased pressure gradient between the two atria. This low velocity of the blood does not usually damage the lining endocardium.

Unrepaired VSD is the most frequent congenital heart disease lesion associated with IE, followed by ventricular outflow tract obstructive lesions, such as with tetralogy of Fallot.

Risk factors for infective endocarditis
High risk Moderate risk Low risk
Prosthetic cardiac valves Mitral valve prolapse with regurgitation Mitral valve prolapse without regurgitation
Previous bacterial endocarditis Isolated mitral stenosis    Atrial septal defect
Cyanotic congenital heart diseases Surgically corrected left to right shunt with no residual shunt  
Mitral regurgitation
Ventricular septal defect
Uncorrected left to right shunt (except ASD)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman underwent mitral valve replacement for severe MR, 5 years ago. She is now posted for an elective colonoscopy, for evaluation of altered bowel habits. What is the recommendation regarding antibiotic prophylaxis for this patient?

choices.text: Amoxicillin, 2g orally, taken 30 to 60 minutes before the procedure
Clindamycin 600mg orally, taken 30 minutes before the procedure
Ampicillin, 2g IM or IV  60 minutes before the procedure

questions.solution:
Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required in patients undergoing genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures even if they have a high-risk cardiac lesion for developing infecting endocarditis (e.g., prosthetic valve).

Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for patients who are undergoing dental procedures, invasive respiratory tract procedures, and procedures on the infected skin.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for each of the following patients undergoing dental procedures, except:

choices.text: A patient with palliative shunt for cyanotic CHD
A patient with previous CABG surgery
Patient with valvulopathy post cardiac transplantation
A patient with prosthetic heart valve

questions.solution:
Routine antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not recommended for patients with previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery. They do not have a long-term risk of infection.

High-risk cardiac lesions, for which endocarditis prophylaxis is advised before dental procedures are:

  • Prosthetic heart valves
  • Prior endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair
  • Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to prosthetic material
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for patients with acquired valvular heart diseases.

Standard regimen: Amoxicillin 2g per orally is given 1-hour prior to surgery. In patients with penicillin allergy, clarithromycin, and azithromycin 500mg per orally can be given.

questions.text: The blood culture of a patient with suspected infective endocarditis is positive for gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment for infective endocarditis with streptococci consists of penicillin with gentamicin for 2 weeks.

Penicillin G (2-3mU IV Q4h) or Ceftriaxone (2g single dose daily) can be given as a monotherapy for 4 weeks.

Staphylococcus aureus infecting native valve Vancomycin
Staphylococcus aureus infecting prosthetic valves Vancomycin + Gentamicin + Rifampin
Enterococci Ampicillin + Gentamicin
HACEK group Ceftriaxone or Ampicillin + Sulbactam
Coxiella burnetti Doxycycline + Hydroxychloroquine
Bartonella Doxycycline + Gentamicin

    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
The first-line agents used in the management of Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) infections are trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole), meropenem, minocycline, and ceftazidime (3rd generation cephalosporin).

Other options:

Option A: Burkholderia species are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and polymyxins.

Option C: Tigecycline is less effective in the case of Burkholderia infections.

Option D: Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporins have the same mechanism of action and compete for the same binding site. Hence, it is not a rational drug combination. 

BCC is a group of bacteria known for causing severe respiratory distress and septicemia, particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). BCC organisms are also found in ICU patients and individuals with chronic granulomatous disease, leading to lung disease. BCC colonization in CF patients prior to lung transplantation increases the risk of death during the early transplant period.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Acute rheumatic fever is caused due to infection with group A streptococcus (GAS), which is Streptococcus pyogenes. It usually follows a streptococcal sore throat or scarlet fever. Other groups of streptococci do not cause acute rheumatic fever. 

The pathogenesis of the development of ARF is based on the concept of molecular mimicry. The antibodies which are produced against M protein and N-acetyl glucosamine of group A streptococci, bind to and damage the human endothelial cells.

It mainly affects children between 5-14 years of age. Patients have various rheumatologic, cardiac, and neurological manifestations. Modified Jone's criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. 

The main aim of treatment of rheumatic fever is to relieve symptoms, prevent inflammation and prevent further infections by group A streptoccus by the use of penicillins.

questions.text: What is the most common clinical feature seen in patients with acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution: The most common clinical feature of acute rheumatic fever is carditis followed by polyarthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Sydenham’s chorea?

choices.text: Affects mainly the head and upper limbs
Occurs within 3 weeks of streptococcal infection
Only restricted to one half of the body

questions.solution:
Choreiform movements in Sydenham’s chorea is mainly seen in the head & upper limbs.

Sydenham chorea is characterized by the presence of involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements of the hands, arms, shoulders, feet, legs, face, and trunk. The movements may be generalized or restricted to one side of the body.

It follows a long latent period (more than 6 months) and therefore can occur alone without any other clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of subcutaneous nodules palpated in a patient with acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Subcutaneous nodules are commonly present in hands, feet, elbows, and occiput.

They are firm, painless, and freely movable subcutaneous nodules, present over the bony prominences of hands, feet, elbow, and occiput. They are a delayed manifestation of rheumatic fever and are usually associated with carditis.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a minor criterion according to modified Jones criteria for diagnosis of rheumatic fever in low risk population?
  1. Reduced PR interval
  2. Subcutaneous nodules
  3. ESR ≥60 mm
  4. Erythema marginatum
  5. Polyarthalgia
questions.solution:
ESR ≥60 mm and polyarthralgia are a part of minor criteria for the low-risk population among the given options.

The major and minor criteria for arthritis differ in low risk and medium to high-risk populations.

  • For low-risk populations, polyarthritis is a major criterion and polyarthralgia is a minor criterion.
  • In the medium to high-risk populations, polyarthritis, polyarthralgia, monoarthritis are major criteria and monoarthralgia is a minor criterion.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of joint pain seen in patients with rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
In rheumatic fever, joint pain is usually asymmetric.

Characteristic features of arthritis of acute rheumatic fever are:

  • Migratory- the pain moves from one joint to another over a period of hours
  • Involvement of large joints – most commonly knees, ankle, hips & elbows
  • Asymmetric
  • Highly responsive to salicylates

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the clinic with skin lesions as shown in the image. On examination, body temperature is 38.5 °C, ESR and ASLO titers are elevated. What is true about the skin finding?

choices.text: Generally occurs in patients with carditis

questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of rheumatic fever and the skin finding shown in the image is erythema marginatum. It generally occurs in patients with carditis. 

Erythema marginatum is a pink, non-pruritic rash that generally occurs on the upper part of the arms or trunk but not on the face. It extends from the centre with an irregular serpiginous border. As the size of the rash increases, the center of the rash returns to normal, while the borders remain pink. Hence it is named erythema marginatum.

The rash may also become more prominent after a hot shower.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: Evidence of preceding streptococcal infection is not essential for making a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in patients presenting with:
questions.solution:
Evidence of preceding streptococcal infection for making diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is not required in the presence of chorea.

Chorea is frequently a late finding of ARF. When chorea appears, major findings, minor findings and findings of preceding streptococcal infection would have been disappeared.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever develops a new-onset murmur. His echocardiography is likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Characteristic initial valvular manifestation in acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is mitral regurgitation.

Damage of the valves leads to mitral regurgitation in the early stages. With repeated episodes of rheumatic fever, there is thickening, calcification, and stenosis of the affected valve.

Mitral regurgitation is the most common cardiac lesion in ARF, while mitral stenosis is the most common lesion in rheumatic heart disease.

Other cardiac manifestations of acute rheumatic fever include myocardial inflammation that can also affect electrical conduction pathways, leading to P-R interval prolongation (first-degree atrioventricular block or rarely higher-level block) and softening of the first heart sound.

questions.text: The prevalence of rheumatic valvular heart disease peaks between:
questions.solution:
The prevalence of rheumatic valvular heart disease peaks between 25-40 years.

Acute rheumatic fever is mainly a disease of children and is common between 5–14 years of age and rare in a person aged more 30 years. In contrast to this, rheumatic valvular heart disease is common between 25-40 years.

questions.text: The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is:
questions.solution:
The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is sodium valproate.

Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting movements.

Medications used to treat Sydenham chorea are:

  • Mild cases: managed by providing a calm environment
  • Severe cases: dopamine antagonists like haloperidol, pimozide, or antiepileptic medications like sodium valproate (preferred due to no extrapyramidal side effects) and carbamazepine
  • Since Sydenham chorea is thought to be an immune-mediated disorder, steroids are effective in the treatment of severe or refractory cases.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. His ESR on admission is 80mm/hr. There is no evidence of carditis. A diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever is made and treatment is initiated. How long will you put the patient on secondary prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a rheumatic fever without carditis. He should be given prophylaxis till 21 years of age as the duration of secondary prophylaxis is 5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer).

Secondary prophylaxis is given for patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF). These patients are at a higher risk of developing a further episode of ARF after a group A streptococcal infection. Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. 

The antibiotics that can be given for secondary prophylaxis are:

  • Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks (Best antibiotic)
  • Oral penicillin V (250 mg) given twice daily (less effective than benzathine penicillin G)
  • Erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily (For patients allergic to penicillin)

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) recommendation for duration of secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever

Category

Duration after the last attack

Rheumatic fever without carditis

  

5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual heart disease (no valvular disease)

  10 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis and residual heart disease (persistent valvular disease)

10 years or until 40 years of age (whichever is longer), sometimes lifelong prophylaxis
